title: Monday, 6th August, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:02am

Okay, let's get going.

Kiwi-juice hello
VV75 morning

Good morning, welcome, hello. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with etc.

VV75 why the sudden jump in the DAXx just now?
Alchemy30 morning
Viking1 Turkey ?
Grouchmonkey Hola!
BE11:05am

.... And I'm not just sure where to begin. Sterling would be the obvious point of entry but ..... uh, Turkey and Dax seem to be where the readership is going.

Blank canvas morning all
Swedish Chef Morning from a damp Fort William. HSBC?
11:05 am
BE11:05am

So! Turkey. Getting kicked for no obvious reason.

BE11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-ab77-f854c65a4465

BE11:06am

That story provides a ticklist of concerns .....

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Investors have become deeply concerned over several factors:

Inflation is running at almost 16 per cent, exacerbated by the tumbling lira;
The US has hit two senior government ministers with sanctions over Turkey’s detainment of an American pastor over espionage and terrorism charges;
President Erdogan’s appointment of his son-in-law to lead a powerful economic and finance ministry after the leader’s election win this June;
Questions about central bank independence (which accelerated after policymakers bucked expectations for a rate rise in July);
Growing economic imbalances.

VV75 Erdogan isn't an obvious enough reason?
BE11:06am

Though as always with market reporting, we have to ask: "why today?"

Viking1 I see Frankfurt continues to support German companies wishing to conduct business in Iran,perhaps Westminster group should set branch office in FFT?
Fox Good morning all
BE11:07am

(@VV75: Erdoğan became PM in 2003. Is your argument that people have only just noticed?)

Fox I see Spire is down 22%.
VV75 he only just got his renewed and supersized powers
11:08 am
BE11:08am

The answer could well be, as it often is in August, that liquidity gets tighter and there are more junior people pushing the buttons, which leads to rather more skittish responses.

Manxish Morning each
VV75 demonstrated by among others the naming of his son in law
Fox Why did they turn down the 315p bid from Mediclinic? Now 190p!
Grouchmonkey Those who were asking about IWG last week have got their answer...

Because of Turkey’s imprisonment of Pastor Andrew Brunson.

BE11:11am

BE11:12am

Mouselet That starts to sound like a last-straw argument. Erdogan in 2003 and Erdogan today are really quite different people
Mouselet And Turkey has certain weirdnesses (half a dozen local banks and a great deal of central pressure to lend) that make 16% inflation rather more than even usually problematic
BE11:13am

And a short line from Merrill ....

BE11:13am

Increase in inflation erodes real policy buffer relative to peers. Given large fx needs, capital flows should weigh on TRY. Orthodox policy adjustment is needed to avoid a hard landing scenario. Rates, the currency and EXD (vs. rating) are not cheap due to rising inflation and external imbalances.

hedgehog spire ?
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Course, we shouldn't start a Monday morning with too much on the Turkish economy. Don't want to be accused of clickbait.

undefined
BE11:14am

Okay, so Spire.

11:14 am
Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 193.00, down 54.2 (-21.93%), High: 195.80, Low: 178.60, Volume: 4.37m
BE11:14am

Currently fighting it out with IWG for the biggest FTSE 350 faller position.

BE11:15am

And ..... it's a profit warning. Another one.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Driven, once again, by the NHS.

BE11:15am

Morgan Stanley can take us through the detail.

BE11:16am

This morning Spire provided a 1H FY18 trading update, which included a profit warning. Company expects EBITDA to be materially lower than in FY17, partly driven by a weaker top line from softer NHS business. No specific EBITDA guidance has been provided. For FY18E Thomson Reuters EBITDA consensus is 150mn (MSe: 149mn) vs. FY17A of 150mn. For 1H FY18 Spire's pre-announcement is for Sales of 475mn vs. our 489mn (-3% below), EBITDA of 66mn vs. our 79mn (-16% below). As a reminder, over the past 3 years, 2H EBTIDA has been lower than 1H EBITDA by an average of -12%; hence for simplicity reasons, if we apply the same maths for 2H FY18E, we would get to an FY18E EBITDA of 124mn or a hypothetical downgrade of -17% to consensus. On the balance of probabilities we see a FY18E consensus EBITDA downgrade of more than -10%. Overall the pressure on the share price today, will be somewhat offset by Mediclinic's stake in Spire.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Now, I say it's the NHS .... where the problem is waiting lists and has resulted in Spire revenue for that line down 10%

BE11:18am

But waiting lists have a natural balance for Spire, as more patients decide to fund their hip replacements themselves.

BE11:18am

Self-pay was up 8.3%, meaning if you net those off you only get a 1% revenue decline.

Excel Developer ping
11:19 am
BE11:19am

The bigger surprise is on costs, and the appearance that management has lost all grip of them.

BE11:19am

Here's JP Morgan.

BE11:19am

The company cites ongoing tough NHS conditions, but actually total revenues were only down 1%. We have spoken with the company, and while clearly disappointed with the outcome, it is confident in the medium term outlook, with the cost investment expected to drive an uptick in
revenues, and it has reiterated medium term guidance given earlier this year. Nonetheless, investors are likely to question how the cost base has been so poorly forecasted since the Capital Markets Day in late April to result in such a material miss.

J L Hello all..
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Note also that when I say cost inflation it's not doctors and stuff being paid more. It seems to be, in the main, central costs and telemarketing.

Patience Re Spire: have often wondered whether they put much effort into finding clients in Scandinavia and the Low Countries - value of sterling must make them competitive.
Div Morning all. FirstGroup - breakup?
BE11:24am

Note also the perception that management had lowballed guidance post the regular profit warnings last year.

Mouselet I have always thought that what made the pain of an arthritic hip much more endurable was constant telemarketing from competing hip replacers
BE11:24am

Against that you have the Mediclinic stake as a valuation backstop .... but really, how much does Mediclinic need another turnaround project? Dunno.

11:24 am
undefined

https://www.telegr...-break-up-rumours/

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Rivals of transport giant FirstGroup are circling the struggling bus and rail operator amid hopes that a break-up is on the cards.

BE11:28am

Carefully phrased lead, that. Oh, and the top ten shareholder quote.

BE11:28am

I am pleased that (new CEO) Wolfhart has a twinkle in his eye and is getting stuck in to an executive-type role. He wants all the businesses to be run separately and nothing is ruled out … This isn’t empire building, this is how you extract value for shareholders.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

"I'm pleased that the boss of the stock I bought that fell to a multi-year low is on the record as having launched a strategic review."

BE11:29am

Which, fair enough I guess.

BE11:30am

You'll remember FirstGroup launched the review post the PE offer failing, and that all divisions were included.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

In terms of the SOTP, I'll turn to this old Citi note.

BE11:30am

BE11:31am

Not a huge amount of trapped value there, tbh. And the market's response to all this seems reasonable.

Tom Dalgleish Have to say I saw it coming with First many years ago
11:31 am
FirstGroup PLC (FGP:LSE): Last: 91.50, up 1.45 (+1.61%), High: 92.05, Low: 90.20, Volume: 471.61k

IWG, then?

11:32 am
IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 232.90, down 67.1 (-22.37%), High: 240.00, Low: 222.00, Volume: 8.02m
Div @BE thanks for that
BE11:32am

Bids off, interims poor.

BE11:33am

The argument with IWG for what feels like at least two years or so was that Dixon probably wanted to sell.....

11:33 am
BE11:33am

.........but if he's selling, it's probably not a great sign about the market.

BE11:34am

And so it transpires. No acceptable offers.

Excel Developer GBPUSD 11 month low
BE11:34am

Peel Hunt incoming.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

IWG has decided not to pursue any of the mooted bids, on the basis that no acceptably priced bid was likely to be forthcoming. Given that all bidders faced the challenge of gauging how much further the aggressive action of WeWork and others will go, before levelling off and, eventually, easing, and that earnings are in a downgrade cycle, this was an exercise in catching a falling knife.

BE11:35am

A month ago, IWG announced that it expected EBITA to be £15m-£20m less than previously expected for FY18E (y/e Dec), citing additional growth costs and underperformance in the UK. As a result, we moved our PBT for FY18/19/20E from £180m/203m/225m to £160m/187m/212m. This was too high, and after H1 PBT reported today at £54.3m, down 33% yoy, well below our £70m tentative forecast, we reduce our FY18/19/20E again to £145m/175m/200m, EPS of 12.6p/15.1p/17.3p (consensus is difficult to assess given that most estimates are out of date or analysts were embargoed). Much depends on H2, with a H1/H2 split of FY18E EBIT being £60m/£100m, which requires a recovery in performance rather than just seasonality, and for which visibility is therefore low.

BE11:36am

.... and Stifel.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

This comes as a significant surprise after the numerous deadline extensions since May. The interim results highlight mature revenue growth of +2.4% (cc), operating profit -29% (cc) and the announcement of a share buyback programme, with little detail available. Whilst management flagged lower profits at a trading update in June, the 1H profit decline is greater than we anticipated. A strengthened order book means the Board are confident that the full-year results will be in line with management expectations. We were one of few analysts to update numbers post-June, and are forecasting adj. operating profit of £161.8m.

BE11:37am

And RBC.

casapinos Note to self- sell any company that turns down a takeover bid
BE11:37am

We believe IWG has an unrivalled market position, significant expansion potential and strong structural growth drivers. However, with the company continuing to embark on an aggressive expansion plan, and credibility still low, we believe it will be sometime before the market will give the benefit of the doubt.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 712.70, down 3.1 (-0.43%), High: 714.00, Low: 706.50, Volume: 8.80m
Excel Developer ECB liqudity ops?
jmcs what about Turkey and upcoming debt servicing? https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2018/08/06/1533528000000/Turkey-s-corporates-need--the-mother-and-father-of-all-evil-/#myft:notification:daily-email:content
BE11:47am

PBT in line, revs and CET1 lower.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Underlying, pre-provisions, a wee bit weak. But nothing particularly new.

BE11:48am

Here's Goldman.

BE11:48am

HSBC 2Q18 underlying PBT of US$6.1bn was in line with GS/company compiled consensus expectations. Modestly weaker underlying revenues (-2% vs. GSe and consensus) were offset by better-than-expected provisions as well as higher associates income. CET1 CAR and BVPS were below GS/consensus largely on negative FX translation impact (GBP depreciation against USD impacting meaningfully). We tweak our 2018-2020 EPS estimates +0.4% to -1.0%, lower BVPS estimates by ~4% to reflect changed FX and modestly lower our 12m RIM-based TP to HK$84 (implies 1.28X 2019E P/B) from HK$85. We maintain our Buy rating with our revised TP offering 16% potential upside plus 5.5% dividend yield.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Positives:
Lower credit costs: Credit costs for 2Q18/1H18 were 10bp/8bp n of loans. Stage 3 loans fell to 1.4% of total at end-June vs. 1.6% at end-Mar. The group benefited from write backs in Oil and Gas exposures, with the management continuing to see the credit environment as stable.
n Higher associate income: Associate income was up 16% yoy during 1H18 led by higher BoCOM and SAAB profit contribution, up 16%/38% yoy.
n Underlying NIM improvement: 1H18 NIM was up 3bp/2bp hoh/yoy led by higher $ bloc interest rates and better deposit spreads therein. 2Q18 NIM was stable qoq as the positive Asia consumer NIM progression (from HIBOR moves) was offset by higher liquidity requirements for UK Non Ring Fenced Bank.
n Solid loan growth: Group loans were up 3% qoq and 5% ytd led by HK and UK.
Group deposits were up 2% qoq. The solid balance sheet growth coupled with underlying NIM expansion led reported group NII to be up 2.5% qoq/9.4% yoy.

BE11:49am

Negatives:
n Jaws: 1H18 saw 5.6pp negative jaws as 2% revenue growth was accompanied by 8% cost growth. HSBC stepped up investments in strategic growth and digital initiatives this year. Although management is committed to delivering positives jaws for 2018 (and beyond), the delivery looks increasingly unlikely. We model 1.5pp negative jaws for 2018, followed by around 2pp positive for 2019 and 2020.
Negative FX translation: Broader USD strength especially its appreciation n against GBP (GBP was 6% lower qoq on spot) led to 4% lower BV and 20bp hit to CET1 CAR qoq. Whilst this is not fundamental, this is likely to reflect in consensus estimates and hence have a bearing on the share price.
n Softer revenues: A mix of negative FX translation, weaker wealth management revenues in HK (-12% qoq) and lower Global markets income (FICC, equities -12%, -17% yoy for 2Q). That said, group revenues were up 2% yoy for 2Q as well as 1H18, and more importantly revenue in 4 key businesses was up a combined c.7% yoy during 2Q.

alewis2005 v quiet today - everyone on holidays?
BE11:50am

And Citi, listening to the conference call so you don't have to.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

NII Sensitivity Outlook – Questions around the reduced NII sensitivity to rate changes, especially for USD: +25bps $107m (2Q18) vs $227m (1Q18). Increased competition for USD offshore deposits, including in HK. Also an increased switch into time deposits. For other currencies, NII sensitivity has increased, esp GBP ($218m vs $147m FY), HKD, EUR. UK rate rise last week will add c$40m to UK RBWM for the rest of the year.

BE11:51am

Consensus Revenues High? – Cons u/l revenues of $55.8bn for FY18 (Citi $55.1bn) appears challenging after the 2% miss in 2Q18 on NII and u/l revenues. 1H18 u/l revenues annualized are c$55.1bn. Management will achieve their positive jaws target if u/l costs and revenues are flat hoh, but CEO Flint noted that he will not reduce investments/cut costs based on non-cash or accounting items.

Excel Developer only EU news I can fathom that caused European equities to step up is EU blocks Iran sanctions to protect European companies. Is this plausible? https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-usa-eu/eu-says-it-deeply-regrets-reimposed-us-sanctions-on-iran-idUSKBN1KR0XI
BE12:00pm

There was a big Brexit note on my screen from Goldman a moment ago but I've lost it. One moment ....

Penny FTAV ML taking a summer break this Aug I assume?
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Since the Brexit Referendum, we have expected the UK to (i) leave the EU Single Market and (ii) agree a tariff-free trade deal to cover its trade in goods with the EU. We continue to expect relatively little by way of an agreement for trade in services, with only a narrow agreement for financial services, in a ‘Canada-plus’ type trade deal. Relative to this central case, the risk of a disorderly exit has, however increased in recent weeks

BE12:01pm

(@Penny: last two weeks of August is the current plan.)

BE12:01pm

..... Oh, actually, this came out on Friday. But I'll quote it anyway.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

n An agreement on the end-state will not be reached quickly... The UK and EU
have agreed that, provided an exit agreement is reached (and a ‘crashing out’ of
the EU is avoided), then a status quo-based transitional period will apply from
March 2019 to end-2020. The UK government has also outlined proposals for its
preferred Brexit end-state which would follow that transitional period. It is similar
to our assumed base case for the end-state and focuses on securing a trade deal
for trade in goods.
n ... nor need it be reached quickly. Avoiding a disorderly exit suits most, if not
all, groups shaping the Brexit negotiation. Doing so requires that the UK and EU
agree a ‘framework’ for the Brexit end-state. This does not require a final deal for
the end-state to be agreed by March and would postpone clarification of the
end-state beyond March. Complex details can then be dealt with in the status
quo-based transition. This is the main reason why we continue to expect, in our
base case, an orderly withdrawal followed by a transitional period and then a
‘Canada-plus’ type trade deal.
n The risk of a disorderly exit has, however, risen owing to the increased risk
that domestic UK politics resists postponing clarification of the complex
details on the end-state beyond March.
n Our current macro forecast is for GDP growth at a pace close to the UK’s
diminished rate of growth of potential over the next two years of 1½% p.a.
This outlook is more dependent on the UK’s withdrawal from the EU being
orderly than it is on the details of the end-state agreement.

Penny william hill - bit of early morning excitement on back of broker upgrades and Sunday Times article
BE12:03pm

BE12:03pm

Amid such elevated political uncertainty, some fundamentals remain.
From a macro perspective, Brexit is a pre-announced, negative n trade and labour
supply shock. While tariffs are unlikely (and, in any case, are generally small),
non-tariff barriers and frictions to trade and migration will rise post-Brexit.
n It is a mistake to think that there is a smooth, continuous range of options between
soft Brexit (à la Norway, which is in the EU Single Market) and some harder Brexit
based on precisely how much alignment with EU rules the UK chooses.
n Instead, there is a discontinuity in this range of options based on whether the UK is
inside or outside the Single Market.
n While events can conceivably shift the UK from its current path in several directions,
this current path involves the UK leaving the Single Market in its Brexit end-state (in
2021 or later) and leaving the EU’s main institutions in March 2019, with a status
quo-based transitional period in between.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

You know what'd be fun now? If May tried to cut off a leadership challenge by calling another election. Secure Mandate 2.0. Or at least threatening it.
